Temu ( $PDD) has moved fast in Mexico. By Q2 2025 its traffic share reached 15.98%, edging past MercadoLibre $MELI and Amazon $AMZN to take the top spot. In less than two years, it has become the country’s largest e-commerce platform by traffic.

Why Mexico? The fundamentals line up almost perfectly. The local online retail market grew 20% in 2024 to $43B, smartphone penetration is deepening, and consumers are obsessed with cost-effectiveness — the exact products China’s supply chains churn out at scale.

Temu isn’t stopping at traffic dominance. It’s now opening up individual seller accounts locally, dropping barriers and effectively creating a low-cost, low-restriction entry point. The platform runs on a semi-managed model: Temu controls front-end traffic, marketing, and logistics standards, while merchants focus on sourcing, fulfillment, and returns. In practice, it means Temu can dictate user experience while giving sellers reach they could never achieve alone.

The formula is simple: funnel China’s supply chain into Mexico’s under-served mass market, back it with platform traffic, and let pricing pressure do the rest. That’s how Temu leapfrogged MercadoLibre and Amazon.
